reviewText:
I was never a big fan of classic adventure games, though Gemini Rue did manage to grab me.  While a small game, it is very well-made with a good story and voice acting.  Gameplay is a bit clumsy as adventure games often are, requiring actions to be performed through an inventory menu rather than having separate keys for separate actions.

The best part about the game is the well-balanced puzzle design.  One of the big pitfalls I've found with adventure games is making the puzzles too difficult to understand while others make the game so simple that there's hardly any player interaction required.  This one manages to find a good balance though there are still a couple parts that get confusing.  It is one of the best examples I've found outside Amanita games though.

The really big disappointment for me was the ending.  I don't want to spoil anything but the ending just didn't make sense to me.  I like how the story ended up, but the way it was done just didn't seem right.

In any case, it's a high quality adventure game that doesn't succumb to common adventure game pitfalls.  Don't expect amazing artwork though, being made in an ancient adventure game engine with very low resolution, low bit depth color graphics.

reviewText:
I constantly find myself torn by games like Gemini Rue; on the one hand, they exude aesthetic and narrative charm, with lovingly crafted characters, worlds, and stories, which are always the main reason I and many others are drawn to them, but on the other hand they are almost always a desperately frustrating gaming experience, bogged down by puzzles that are long, disjointed, and (in many cases) narratively inappropriate.

The latter issue is what bugs me the most, and what makes playing these games so frustrating. For example, there is one particular puzzle where you need to call a guy using your communicator and try to get some information out of him. If you don’t choose the specifically correct dialogue options when speaking to him, he hangs up. This is quite believable and is probably what an actual human would do. Of course, this game being what it is, you can just call him again and again and again and try a different set of dialogue options each time, and every single time he responds as though you’re speaking to him for the first time. It doesn’t matter how many times you call him – even on the fifth call, he responds as though you’ve not just spoke to him four times previously using ever so slightly different variations on your script. If this were an actual person speaking to another human being, calling the person again and trying the same script with tiny variations would get you laughed at and hung up on immediately.

The above kind of puzzle is narratively inappropriate because it is just not how a human being would behave at all. The playing experience stops being a nicely flowing story of which you, the gamer, are an integral part, and becomes an arbitrary clicking exercise, jarring you out of the narrative. The above puzzle is also guilty of another puzzle design sin: it seems to exist solely to pad out the game. It isn’t hard, don’t require much thought, and just involves trying different combinations over and over again, wasting a lot of time in the process. I wish I could say this was the only example of this, but it sadly isn’t.

Many of the puzzles in Gemini Rue aren’t game ruining, and they aren’t completely nonsensical (unlike other infamous examples from this genre: the rubber ducky puzzle in The Longest Journey, anyone?) but they are generally quite wonky and boring. At one point you have to find a Carbon Ray Stabilizer to fix your lockpicks (why a Carbon Ray Stabilizer, I have no idea). Rather than buying it from a vendor or asking someone where to find one, you have to search around an abandoned building with some crates hidden towards the back. It’s not even easy to get to the crates – you have to get someone to help you. You have to see the crates when exploring, think “hang on, they must be really important” not “they’re just some old crates at the back of an abandoned room” and then go out of your way to work out how to get to them. Lo and behold, there’s one in the crates. Why is it there? I have no idea. I was just aimlessly exploring because I had no idea what to do next and just so happened to stumble on the solution. That’s not a satisfying solution to the problem, and it makes absolutely no narrative sense.

The strange thing is that I often feel like I’m crazy for feeling this way; support for old-school point and click games seems overwhelming, and any critical opinions seem to be drowned in a sea of nostalgic rage. I seriously want to love games like this, I really do, but their puzzles make them a gargantuanly frustrating experience. If you’re willing to have a walkthrough in one hand at all times and you’re willing to suspend your disbelief through some poorly designed puzzles, then I would probably recommend this. Unfortunately, I felt frustrated more than I felt enjoyment, which is not something I want to experience in a game.

reviewText:
Outstanding adventure game.

I didn't realise that classic adventure games could be so immersive! I enjoyed latest Telltale work, but I would hardly place them in adventure genre. Gemini Rue on the other hand is a real classic point-and-click adventure game, though you could say that the biggest flaws and offenders of the genre were left out. You won't find any illogical obstacles and puzzles, pixel hunting or absurd item combining.

What you get is a great sci-fi noiresque story, where you are a detective looking for his lost brother on some god-forgotten planet. Later the game opens up and lets you switch between the two main characters, the detective and the missing brother. It really does feel like you're detective, getting dirty and doing the groundwork: asking around, getting true identity of people, searching information about them in database. Top this with action sequences where you can cover and shoot at your enemies and you really get an exceptional adventure game. Voice acting and writing is astounding and the story itself is intriguing and suprising. All of that in a indie game made by the handful of people! I did enjoy the visual style of the game and I think it befits the game, but I guess some people could argue that the resolution is too low.

Overall, superb game, highly recommended. A great reminder that the adventure games are a great way to tell a story and don't have to be obscure and plagued with bizzare puzzles.

reviewText:
I think this is one of the greatest science fiction point-and-click adventure games you could find on steam. It's got old school pixel graphics and just great voice acting all-around. The puzzle elements are also a lot of fun. The story behind Gemini Rue may seem derivative. It's set in a universe like the TV show Firefly and it's movie counterpart Serenity, it has the tone and feel of Blade Runner and has the plot of Total Recall. But it never made it bad. It's just taking the good stuff on what I like about science fiction.

You play as Azriel Odin, an ex-assassin that is looking for his brother on the planet of Barrucus, which is part of a Gemini Star System, a system that won it's independence after a war and is now run by a crime syndicate known as the Boryokudun. The other character you will get to play is Delta-Six whom is a patient of a mysterious facility. This is all I can say about the story without going into spoilers.

Throughout the game, you talk to characters, solve puzzles, do detective-like work to learn about things and occasionally go on shoot-outs. There's an interesting shooting mechanic in the game that you will learn how to use.

All of the characters in Gemini Rue are well written and feel real. The philosophical themes of identity and memories are also explored in this game and is pretty much what the game wants to explore and talk about. There are a couple downsides of this game. Some of the puzzles are little too difficult and the fictional universe that is offered in Gemini Rue remains mostly unexplored with the exception of a single city on one planet and a facility somewhere else.

But I recommend this game to Science fiction, cyberpunk and story adventure fans. It's definitely a must-buy!

reviewText:
An engaging and immersive cyberpunk point n click adventure game with a great story and likeable characters. The story has interesting themes and is portrayed in an interesting fashion. The voice acting fit the characters well and they were all unique. I also liked how the music was very understated and complimented the scenes nicely. It was definitely satisfying to play through to the end and see how the story unfolded, leaving a very satisfying conclusion.

The graphics are beautifully drawn and make the world feel immersive. Some backgrounds are only seen for a few seconds yet are still richly detailed and almost breathtaking to look at, so I commend the developer for that.

The puzzles hit the right balance between challenging and logical, there weren't any weird and crazy parts of the game's internal logic. Some areas of the game can be a little tricky and annoying to figure out which part of the map to go to next as you backtrack through familiar areas a few times but nothing too egregious.

There is combat through gunplay. I noticed a couple of glitches such as when a sprite in the background would be placed on the top layer in front of my character in the foreground, but this only happened twice.

Definitely recommended for people who enjoy interesting sci-fi cyberpunk stories with good voice acting and story, especially considering that the majority was drawn, written and programmed by just one student, so props to him for making such an engaging and interesting game. reviewText:
Positive
+ A genuinely intriguing story in a futuristic noir setting; watching the mystery of Azriel Odin and Delta-Six unravel throughout the course of the 5 ½ hour campaign does not drag on in the slightest, with a satisfying conclusion to top it all off
+ In the style of older point and click games (most notably Beneath a Steel Sky), Gemini Rue’s gameplay is a tried and tested formula that doesn’t fail to test the player at times with somewhat obscure puzzles, while still remaining fairly linear
+ The game also manages to effectively capture the graphical style of said older games, with both pixelated environments and character models giving the game a distinctive look; the sound effects and music as well are very well-implemented
+ The amateur voice acting that accompanies the story is surprisingly well-done--especially the main characters--making the games futuristic/noir setting all the more authentic.


Negative
- The few shooting sections, while a nice addition to the point and click gameplay, suffer from awkward controls and mechanics (luckily these sections are few and far between)
- The amount of environments and backgrounds is scarce, leading to you treading familiar ground far too often; some more locations to explore wouldn’t go amiss.


Verdict
“Gemini Rue pays homage to point and click games from the past, while still managing to feel both old and new. With an unforgettable story and quirky puzzles, the few gameplay sections that may try to detract from the experience couldn’t manage to deter me from playing through this gem. I’d easily recommend this game to fans of old adventure games.”

reviewText:
It's a point-and-click adventure game of the older variety (puzzling puzzles and all), which, for some reason, puts some people off from the very outset. Assuming you're not from that group, however, you will find a game with a pretty unique and intriguing story, accompanied by a very fitting noir atmosphere (I hesitate to call it cyberpunk, though similar themes are employed) and well executed retro graphics. On the other hand, the story and the atmosphere are the good parts of the game.

Why do I say that? Well, even when it works the controls, particularly those for shooting, are a bit of an annoyance. The game would've been better without those action sequences, but alas, they're there and can be endured. The main complaint, however, is that the game is rather buggy in game-breaking ways. There are workarounds, but it still makes it a bad product. For example, on Windows 7 x64, the first thing one has to do is to turn the Steam overlay off, or else any alt-tabbing or shift-tabbing means that all dialogue will be in fast-forward mode, making it impossible to follow the plot. Resonance, another game from the same developer, has the same issue, so at least I kind of knew about it.

Next, after a restart my saves just disappeared. Turns out this can be fixed by moving them from \SteamLibrary\steamapps\common\Gemini Rueeslists\Saves
to \SteamLibrary\steamapps\common\Gemini Rue\Saves but why should I have to? Oh, and the escape key needed to access the menu sometimes stops working, at which point one should apparently realize that hitting shift first helps. Oh well, at least I didn't have to patch the game with specific versions of DLL files, but that reportedly happens too.

Now, if you are willing to subject yourself to all of that, there's a nice, really well-voiced sci-fi story in it for you.  If not, you're probably just being sensible. Either way, I can't really recommend paying full price for the game. Sales level prices, yes, but perhaps only to fans of the genre.

reviewText:
Gemini Rue is a point and click adventure game with sparse and limited fighting mechanics in various stages of the game that takes place in a dystopian sci-fi future that could be inspired easily from movies like Blade Runner. As it is expected, you explore the environment and interact with people and objects in order to solve puzzles and eventually proceed. There is also an item called the communicator which lets you communicate with various characters throughout the game but also provides you with all the necessary information and mission status.

You play the role of a man named Azriel who was an ex assassin but now has left his past behind him and works as an officer against the organized crime which is run by a mafia-like group called the Boryokudan. Your formal mission is to aid a man who later helps you on your true mission which is to acquire information about your lost brother Daniel. After infiltrating the Boryokudans and reaviling that there is a secret facility where people are sent there to have their memory whipped out and re-trained to become criminals and that your brother was sent there, you gather your crew and set a new mission, rescuing your brother.

The storyline despite being short is quite compelling and there are nice twists at the end as expected. The overall theme of the game is nicely expressed through the art style with retro like graphics and atmospheric music. However, I would really prefer it if instead the 16 bit overlay the visuals were a little more detailed. In comparison, the audio quality is really impressive for being an indie game. The audio logs are rich and clearly there was put a lot of effort into it. So, the audio and visuals are not side by side in my opinion.

All in all, Gemini Rue is a solid adventure game following the steps of the classic ones, yet it feels fresh and modernized. All friends of the adventure genre should definitely try out this game.

reviewText:
Gemini Rue is a retro-style point and click adventure set on an incredibly atmospheric and stylish backdrop with an engrossing story and deeply challenging puzzles. It has all the hallmarks of classic games within the genre and is of a quality that puts some big-budget modern games to shame today.

You assume the role of two characters in this intertwining story;- Azriel Odin; a former assassin who is searching for his brother whilst looking for personal redemption for his past; and a mysterious hospital patient named 'Delta Six' who's memory has been wiped for reasons unknown. Your job is to collectively discover the secrets that exist in this bleak, corrupt and crime-riddled world and provide a resolution to your characters's plight. As the narrative develops and the story unfolds; you will be hooked. For such a simple 2D game; the story is truly absorbing along with the fully-voiced characters each with an intriguing personality.

The user interface is also extremely well implemented which is pivotal as this game demands complete precision in the execution of tasks and puzzles. It is incredibly complex at times and you will be forgiven for having to look up the occasional solution but it is a testament to the developers on how to create a challenging, thought-provoking and engrossing game.

If you're a veteran of the genre, a fan of adventure games or just looking for a story-driven title that offers a rewarding challenge; Gemini Rue is absolutely unmissable. It captures the essence of classic games perfectly and delivers a powerful and intriguing experience throughout. One of the best titles on Steam

reviewText:
I appreciate this game, but some troubles with the puzzles and the UI leave more to be desired.

The adventure game this one reminds me of is Beneath a Steel Sky.  The graphics are horribly pixilated, just as games from that era were with audio and voice acting to make up for the lack of graphical attractiveness.  And it does make up for it in those areas, the characters have parts that are well written and well performed with a very human story to go alongside it.

The story is one I can appreciate.  The story follows two brothers, one trying to escape a station after having his memory wiped several times and the other trying to find the station and rescue his brother.  I liked it, the reveal happened a lot earlier than the real reveal and the major reveal becomes a lot more predictable the longer you go on through the game.  However, the writing is self-aware of its own predictability and manages use it as part of the build up -to the expected result- without insulting your intellect.  Instead of happening with an unexpected bang, it happens with a silent drone of acceptance, which I thought was what the author was trying to get and fits in with the environment they were building.

Most adventure games tell stories of odd worlds and go out of the way to say how different this world is from the one we live in.  This game tries hard to explain the world with experience and view we can relate to, emphasizing the people without dwelling on the sci fi, dystopia, or technology.  From that standpoint, the game is a lot more serious than most of the games filling the adventure genre.

The UI and puzzles hold the experience back somewhat.  The puzzles follow the standard point and click or dialogue variety with some machine operation and event type obstacles alongside it.  The gunplay they added to the game was clunky and annoying to do.  It's easy once you manage to figure it out but it feels like something to pad the length of the game.  Some of the puzzles also have this feel, as if they were made just to lengthen the game by making you repeat content and without adding to immersion.  The UI also soured me.  It is not terrible, but some of the user unfriendly conventions of early adventure games were adopted alongside the art style.  I did have some problems trying to figure out how to use items in my inventory together, something infrequent in this game and I wish I gave more thought to the tooltip telling me how to do it the one time I had to during the game.

In all, I'd say it has the bones of a good adventure game and is at least as good as the games it emulates.  Unfortunately, the UI, gunplay, and some of the puzzles leave the experience feeling clunky.  A good find for adventure game fans, less so for everyone else.

reviewText:
I’m a bit biased since I don’t like adventure games. The stories are often juvenile, puzzle solutions defy logic and the games themselves don’t have much adventure. The best I can do is say that Gemini Rue isn’t terrible but too many people here are going way overboard on their praise of this game.

The main reason to play adventure games (I think) is for the story. GR’s is a cut above most of what you’ll find in the adventure genre but it’s still not what I’d call “good”. It’s simply okay. Nothing particularly memorable, though there are at least a few twists thrown in.

Likewise, I loathe navigating through the UIs in these games because they often turn simple tasks into complex ones because of poor design. GR has several moments like this, too, where you’ll know what has to be done but have to figure out the exact way the game prefers you do it.

I will give it some points for puzzles at least having rational solutions instead of falling into the trap of “adventure game logic”. When you have to reach a ledge, for example, you’ll pull over a crate to stand on instead of throwing a rubber chicken at a cat who will get a dog to chase it who will knock over a vase which will startle a mule into kicking you up to the ledge. Again, though, it’s so annoying to have to point and click around to figure out the exact right combination of menu instructions to get up on the crate & climb up to the ledge. I’d much rather have a jump or climb button and be playing a different game.

The gunfight minigame is a nice diversion from all the pointing and clicking but is inferior to any action game. It was a fun challenge, at least, to get the Steam achievement for not getting hit once during them.

The graphics are retro, which means they are not so great and are around mid-1990s standards. Considering this, they at least do a good job of conveying the “dirty future” atmosphere the game is going for and set an appropriate mood.

So if you like adventure games, I’d say you will enjoy GR. If you aren’t crazy about the genre, though, you won’t find anything here to change your mind.

I've just finished this noir-esque, philosophical journey with a twist and boy was I entertained.

I'll wrap up my pro's and con's - NO SPOILERS BELOW -

+ setting. max payne meets space opera, what more should I say
+ music & sound. Soundtrack is awesome - game is fully voiced and the environmental sounds are realistic (voices sound different when heard through closed doors, for example)
+ characters. The main protagonist feels like a comic version of Bruce Willis in the 80s (Last Boy Scout!), except he's living in 2229.
+ introduction of characters. Meaning you might not immediately notice who will be very important in the future.
+ dialogues. A bit of fun, a bit of violence, a bit of philosophy. An intriguing cocktail of feelings that makes you wanna keep playing.
+ plot twists. nuff said here.
+ easter egg characters. I didn't find them all - there's an achievement for that (the only cool one, see below)
+ open world feel. Of course the game is very linear, but at certain points you get the feeling you could go everywhere - you just don't want to.

-  graphics. They're just a tiny bit too pixely for a game of this millennium. At certain points there are overlapping errors.
- playability. Had to google how to combine objects in the inventory. Also frantically scrolling around trying to see the cursor change and show anything you can interact with feels good once acomplished, but can be tedious when you're stuck.
- achievements. Only for the hardcore because most of em are a joke: STAIR MASTER - use stairs instead of the elevator, srsly? It does not affect anything. Also, not getting hit in fights (see below) or finding ammo in an adventure game is just... meh...
- gunfights and boxes (I mean crates, not boxing). They're like repetitive, useless mini-games no-one needs; not difficult, either. Feels good to kill a meanie with a headshot though (yes, the game does give that option).

Overall, the pro's are outweighing the con's since they're very big and important pro's and tiny, non-essential con's.

I highly recommend to any fan of point & click, to any fan of darker stories. Although not being replayable really I'll might give it another run (with dev commentary).

Most of the time I feel like I hate cyberpunk. It's a genre that lends itself too well to existential angst and superficial anti-corporatism. The themes of human identity in the face of transhumanism and the threat of all subsuming, monolithic corporation feel overplayed to me. They've lost their appeal to me through sheer overuse.\n\nNonetheless, I can't help but appreciate the aesthetic and style of the genre. There is an inescapable appeal in hard boiled sour old badasses walking the worn wet streets of slums and ghettos orders of magnitude more technologically complex than contemporary society, feebly clinging to their humanity in the face of dilemma after dilemma. For me, Blade Runner captured this atmosphere and mood, and for that it is one of my favorite films. Gemini Rue has also nailed this feeling and ambience, and because of that I keep coming back to it years after my first playthrough. It's not a groundbreaking game, but it's a fantastic experience which is probably well worth your time.

A point/click adventure without a decent story is useless, and Gemini Rue is interesting if you are into futuristic urban dystopia. The best part of the game in my opinion was the part where you could switch between two characters, so if you did get stuck, at least you could switch to the other character's storyline until you were ready to go back and tackle the other point in which you were stuck.  Eventually it all comes together nicely with a satisfactory ending and some fun easter eggs along the way.  The voice acting and sound/music effects actually add to the suspense and game atmosphere, so that's a big plus.\n\nI am not a big fan of the pixelated art style, or my cursor getting momentarily stuck every time it ran into an edge of the screen (hit escape until the menu centers, and then hit it again - you should have your cursor back).  If you aren't into point/click, but the theme interests you, you should give Gemini Rue a go.  Don't know if I'd buy again, but recommended for a playthrough as a good change of pace from action games.

I got it as a gift from a friend (he showed me a list of games and I chose this one, because it was a mix between noire cop shows and sci-fi weirdness) and let me tell you I was not disappointed.  I grew up with point-and-click adventure games and this one was clearly different, if only because the object you use to move foreward don't seem contrived or out-there at all.  No rubberband-and-carrot boomerangs to kick-start a bunny generator so it can release bunnies to form a fluffy bridge to cross.  Nope.  Need to stop a guy from shooting you?  Right click on him, left click on gun, dead.  Need to open window? Right click on it, left click on foot, etc.

It only took me about 3 days of on-and-off play to finish this with just a bit of difficulty.  This game is very good at giving you all the tools you need to succeed, you just have to be paying attention.  Nothing the game makes you do seems trivial.

The story was very well written and I couldn't find any holes in it.  No one breaks character and they're all very unique.

Learning not to use WASD and instead click the screen to move around was a little strange, and sometimes I had trouble moving the characters where I wanted them to go, but it didn't bother me that much.

BONUS: If you're someone who likes references or easter eggs, there are a TON of Battlestar Galactica references in this game. I won't give them all away, but the person who created this was clearly a fan.

Are we defined by our memories?

I've just finished this noir-esque, philosophical journey with a twist and boy was I entertained.

I'll wrap up my pro's and con's - NO SPOILERS BELOW -

+ setting. max payne meets space opera, what more should I say
+ music & sound. Soundtrack is awesome - game is fully voiced and the environmental sounds are realistic (voices sound different when heard through closed doors, for example)
+ characters. The main protagonist feels like a comic version of Bruce Willis in the 80s (Last Boy Scout!), except he's living in 2229.
+ introduction of characters. Meaning you might not immediately notice who will be very important in the future.
+ dialogues. A bit of fun, a bit of violence, a bit of philosophy. An intriguing cocktail of feelings that makes you wanna keep playing.
+ plot twists. nuff said here.
+ easter egg characters. I didn't find them all - there's an achievement for that (the only cool one, see below)
+ open world feel. Of course the game is very linear, but at certain points you get the feeling you could go everywhere - you just don't want to.

-  graphics. They're just a tiny bit too pixely for a game of this millennium. At certain points there are overlapping errors.
- playability. Had to google how to combine objects in the inventory. Also frantically scrolling around trying to see the cursor change and show anything you can interact with feels good once acomplished, but can be tedious when you're stuck.
- achievements. Only for the hardcore because most of em are a joke: STAIR MASTER - use stairs instead of the elevator, srsly? It does not affect anything. Also, not getting hit in fights (see below) or finding ammo in an adventure game is just... meh...
- gunfights and boxes (I mean crates, not boxing). They're like repetitive, useless mini-games no-one needs; not difficult, either. Feels good to kill a meanie with a headshot though (yes, the game does give that option).

Overall, the pro's are outweighing the con's since they're very big and important pro's and tiny, non-essential con's.

I highly recommend to any fan of point & click, to any fan of darker stories. Although not being replayable really I'll might give it another run (with dev commentary).

This game is about as old school as you can get barring text-only, though it proves that there is no such thing as going out of style when it comes to fun.

Story-wise Gemini Rue is a sci-fi noir tale - in the vein of Blade Runner - about a cop searching for his missing brother in a post-war, gangster run corner of the galaxy. It is also the story of a nameless detainee in a mysterious facility where mind erasure and “re-education” are the rule. These two stories run side by side with players alternating between roles, filling in the narrative blanks until they finally come head to head during the game’s climax.

As for the writing, while some of Gemini Rue’s twists, motivations, and dialogue seem hackneyed at times, they can easily be written off as contribution to the game’s pulp roots. The gameplay is mostly solid, with a decent shooting mechanic for the “action” sequences and plenty of point-and-click puzzles to solve. My only gripe is that some clickable objects are very small, requiring one to play “hunt the pixel” in order to interact. More than once this caused me to overlook an otherwise obvious solution.

In the end, Gemini Rue turned out to be a pleasant experience and worth the investment. If you’re a fan of sci-fi noir, classic point-and-click adventure games, or both, you should consider checking it out.

GR never ceases to be a coherent experience with its own logic and sense of freedom. Gemini Rue is an old-school point and click adventure game with some action elements. The game has an involving story and unusually good use of pixelated retro graphics but is somewhat on the easy side.

The game is set in a dystopian future and features a story that starts our mysterious and gradually reveals more about what is going on. The story has philosophical aspects touching on the relationship between memories and personal identity although it doesn't really explore the subjects in any great detail. The story is the best aspect of the game and is helped by the fact that there are two branches of the story unravelling at the same, the two of which later converge. I found the story very appealing and it kept me wanting to keep playing to find out what would happen.

The pixelated graphics suit the atmosphere of the game very well and the visuals are nicely done. I think pixelated graphics have been overused in recent times, but here they are used to good effect.

Sound effects are adequate but nothing special, voice acting on the other hand is considerably above average and matches the personalities of the characters well.

The actual gameplay is the weakest aspect of the game. Puzzles are somewhat bland, not all that creative and mostly a bit too easy. The action sequences are nothing special and don't add much to the game. You could perhaps argue that in a strongly story driven game like this, having easy puzzles may be a good thing, as harder puzzles would only be frustrating when you want to make progress to find out how the story continues. Whether or not you accept that arugment I think that the somewhat lackluster gameplay pulls the game down a bit and keeps it from being the really great game that it could have been.

All in all this is a highly recommended game for all point and click adventure enthusiasts, ar least if you think a good well-told story is at least as important as good gameplay.

reviewText:
Absolutely the best contemporary point-and-click adventure game I've played in years - and I play a lot of adventure games. The characters, the story, the dystopian retro-cyberpunk setting and the clever, yet logical, puzzles all contribute to making this a beautiful adventure that deserves to be praised and regarded as a classic in the years to come.

The game also contains several easter eggs and secrets which, along with the branching dialogue paths in the story, the behind-the-scenes commentary, and the alternative solutions to puzzles, should contribute to its re-playability factor.

The only aspects that I find mar this otherwise flawless gem include the combat scenes (which feature quite heavily towards the end - yes, you can die), the inability to change the resolution from the in-game options menu (which led to some heavy pixellation on my 1920x1080 screen) and the lingering sense that your in-game decisions don't have a large effect on the conclusion of the story.

The best part of the game in my opinion was the part where you could switch between two characters, so if you did get stuck, at least you could switch to the other character's storyline until you were ready to go back and tackle the other point in which you were stuck.  Eventually it all comes together nicely with a satisfactory ending and some fun easter eggs along the way.  The voice acting and sound/music effects actually add to the suspense and game atmosphere, so that's a big plus.\n\nI am not a big fan of the pixelated art style, or my cursor getting momentarily stuck every time it ran into an edge of the screen (hit escape until the menu centers, and then hit it again - you should have your cursor back). Don't know if I'd buy again, but recommended for a playthrough as a good change of pace from action games.

The combat to me feels rather cumbersome - I usually don't play point and clicks in one go due to the puzzle solving nature of it, so have combat in different parts of the game makes me go 'uhh what was I supposed to do again?'. After playing through the whole game and going through the second time, I revisited the tutorial and realized I've totally forgotten about the aiming bit (pressing control button to trigger an aim) and have been shooting blindly, although I managed to get through with my blind shooting. Dying isn't brutal as the game reloads from an auto-save point upon death (although it's better to have your own saves as well to lessen the steps between the auto-save point and the action).

This game has a 'hardcore' kinda feel to it, in a sense that it makes you do one step by step. Like if you wanted to open a door, you MUST walk near it and then open the door. However, I do like the fact you can kick things as well as addition to the normal 'see/talk/pick up' mechanic.

The voice acting is good, and I like the mood the game sets. The little touches in the game like how well animated the rain is, and the sound of the rain gets louder when you open the door to the rain outside is pretty immersive.

Definately a recommendable game if you like a decent storyline, atmospheric mood, decent voice acting despite dated and not-so-great graphics. If you do play this game, I encourage you to save alot as you can have different solutions to certain things in the game and missable acheivements.

The length of the game surprised me, its +- 8 hours. To keep a game of this length engaging is quite an achievement.

Recommendable if: you like adventure games and/or you like a good story and/or like the themes of noir and sci-fi.

Gemini Rue is a fun revamp of the old point n' click experience wrapped up in a twisty, turny sci-fi narrative.  The game spruces up the traditional mechanics by adding slight touches of combat, standard detective sleuthing and other elements, among it's primiarly pixel-hunt littered narrative.

While the graphics are in an old, pixel-based style, they are suitably grimy and dirty for the setting, which makes it work.  No amazing visuals to be found here but more of a classic look that kind of called my memory banks back to Shadowrun, Syndicate and other classic games.  The story is solid with some choice based dialogue and optional achievement objectives, but in reality this game is very straightforward.  It's all about figuring out what to find, where to use and thusly where to go.

The story itself was awesome and even though a few of the twists lingered in the back of my mind like, Oh
date: that's who that is...that's what's happening
recommended:
I still found myself pleasantly surprised here and there.  That whole begotten city, sci-fi touch really did give me fond memories of playing through Shadowrun SNES about 5 times in a row.  Some have complained about clunky gunplay but I was able to win every duel without a hit on medium difficulty on my second playthrough.  Could have probably done it on the first but was still learning the ropes.  The shooting/chase sequences helped to add variety to the standard puzzles and lengthy story expositions.  The thing about the game's story is that once it hooks you, it hooks you.  You'll want to find out what happens and then play it a second time to see if you can notice how things were going to play out.

Controlling two characters for a portion of the game was also a nice touch, and I enjoyed the fact that the majority of the gameplay in the two main locations was different enough that it further freshened up the experience.  Also pleasing was the fact that the majority of the dialogue was done with voice-acting, and even though an amateur team did the work, they did a pretty good job of bring the gruffness and vulnerability to the characters that required these different emotions.

With all of that said Gemini Rue isn't without its flaws.  It took me about 8-9 hours on the first playthrough examining every little thing and over-complicating the puzzles, but once you figure everything out as well as how to be a successful gun dueler, challenge is a pretty moot issue.  This game is not that tough.  My second playthrough was completed in barely 3 hours, so if you are a really keen player with adventure games (I'm a big rusty, getting my legs back), you have the potential to rip through this game pretty quickly.  Most of the times that you will get stuck is because you will completely overcomplicate the solutions.

More depth in the game would have been welcome...some different guns, some unique character attributes, ability to upgrade your skills, etc.  As a first outing this was not a problem, but there was definitely potential for this game to go in REALLY deep.  The experience as it was, wasn't shallow but at times you I felt like I was wishing for all of these other things to crop up in the training experiences which would become tools Azriel could use to complete his missions.  Still, it was mostly satisfying in the way the adventure unfolds and you'll want to keep playing to see just how things go down in the end.

I'd like to write a longer review for this one but it's honestly a pretty simple, easy game with a complex story.  If you get stuck at any point, I guarantee it's because you are thinking about the puzzles too in-depth.  My second playthrough really illustrated to me how short and unchallenging this game really is.  I only missed one achievement and I didn't need a walkthrough to figure anything out.  Most of the times I was stuck was just me creating these elaborate solutions of how I needed to solve a problem.  With that said, Gemini Rue is definitely worth playing for point and click fans who enjoy some other accoutrements to that style of gameplay, yet I can't help but feel I played a game with so much more potential.  Hopefully, there will be a sequel and if so I will definitely support it.

It has some rather unusual elements in a modern Point and Click though - you have combat scenes and you can die in this game. The combat to me feels rather cumbersome - I usually don't play point and clicks in one go due to the puzzle solving nature of it, so have combat in different parts of the game makes me go 'uhh what was I supposed to do again?'. After playing through the whole game and going through the second time, I revisited the tutorial and realized I've totally forgotten about the aiming bit (pressing control button to trigger an aim) and have been shooting blindly, although I managed to get through with my blind shooting. Dying isn't brutal as the game reloads from an auto-save point upon death (although it's better to have your own saves as well to lessen the steps between the auto-save point and the action).

This game has a 'hardcore' kinda feel to it, in a sense that it makes you do one step by step. Like if you wanted to open a door, you MUST walk near it and then open the door. However, I do like the fact you can kick things as well as addition to the normal 'see/talk/pick up' mechanic.

The voice acting is good, and I like the mood the game sets. The little touches in the game like how well animated the rain is, and the sound of the rain gets louder when you open the door to the rain outside is pretty immersive.

Definately a recommendable game if you like a decent storyline, atmospheric mood, decent voice acting despite dated and not-so-great graphics. If you do play this game, I encourage you to save alot as you can have different solutions to certain things in the game and missable acheivements.
